text: although equivalent for integers maybe "greater than or equal to 1" is more clear than "greater than 0"
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/find_cuts.py')

text:
I would go for a more straightforward message.
`'Image has %d slices in direction %s. Therefore the number of cuts must be between 1 and %d. You provided n_cuts=%d' % (this_shape, direction, this_shape, n_cuts)`
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/find_cuts.py')

text:
The error message does not match the condition: Here you are interested in the type. "should" is not strong enough, this is a hard constraints. Maybe something like:
`The number of cuts (n_cuts) must be an integer greater or equal than 1. You provided a value of type %s.`
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/find_cuts.py')

text: Sounds good to me.

title: (19, '', u'nilearn/plotting/find_cuts.py')

text: Tiny comment it looks like the fully correct version is "greater **than** or equal **to** 1" and the alternative winning the google battle is "greater or equal **to** 1". See http://english.stackexchange.com/questions/38287/do-we-say-is-greater-or-equal-to-or-is-greater-or-equal-than for more details.
